content.description: Climb the wall just left of a prominent black-streaked groove, beginning with nice bulbous holds, but ending with small crimps that lead extremely tenuously around a slight bulge on poor footholds.  Frightening
content.location: The Loaf, just left of Sheepherder

content.description: Stand start on knobs and jugs at the left hand side of the North Face of the Loaf.  Move to the right and up on jugs and occasional crimps to top out.  Feet are good.  Downclimb is obvious, on climber's left.
content.protection: Pad, spotter.  Spotter should make sure to move pad, and keep it as anchored as possible, as the ground slopes down to the right.  A fall could conceivably start the climber pad-surfing into a bush.
content.location: This problem lies on the North face of the Loaf.  Croft and Lewis's book doesn't cover this side of the Loaf (only the west side, in picture B3 on p. 165), but indicates on page 164 that there may be a V1 on this face.  I believe the V1 is the well-chalked problem on the arrete to the right, not this problem, which felt much easier, roughly V0-.

content.description:
Really fun climb (kind of a highball). Climb up on some good knobs and crimps into a tall, shallow groove.

Focus on footwork and make some balancey moves to top out.
content.location: Prominent black streak to the right of The Rising

content.description: Two different starts both go to a crimp above head-height.  Move up and left to finishing jug above bush.
Some thin crimps, balancey sidepulls and precise edging lead to better holds up high and a much more secure finish than the lines to the right.

The full traverse of the Loaf boulder's west face. Hard crimping and technical footwork take you across perfect rock. Start on the obvious flake just left of The Rising, traverse right and finish on Dough Boy.
content.location: Leftmost hold on the west face of the boulder

content.description: Right to Left traverse of the Loaf boulder. Climbs like a route. Start on Sheepherder, traverse left, and finish as for The Rising.

Begin six or eight feet to the right of "Sheepherder" and climb up very thin crimps on a gray, convex face, aiming for the patina up higher, which doesn't end up providing much in the way of positive holds. A fairly sustained and footwork-intensive problem.
